Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Story:
I was sipping my morning coffee when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, someone I knew from my running group. “Hey, could you help me move some boxes this afternoon? I’m moving to a new place and could really use an extra hand.” I glanced at my calendar, feeling the familiar tug of obligation. As an acquaintance, I knew the right thing was to say yes, to be supportive and helpful, especially since Mark rarely asked for favors.

But my mind was already racing with the day’s real challenge. As the lead architect on the new high-rise hospital, I was scheduled to review the final safety compliance documents that afternoon. The inspection was tomorrow, and any oversight could mean catastrophic consequences. My team and the hospital board were counting on me to catch every detail, to ensure that every regulation was met and every life protected.

I felt the pressure mounting from both sides—Mark’s hopeful request and the weight of professional responsibility. My stomach twisted as I tried to figure out how to be both the helpful friend and the vigilant architect, knowing that I couldn’t fully be both at the same time.
